bibl.title: Letter from Earl I. Brown to Henry Rose Carter, March 23, 1915

div1.p: Brown grants Carter permission to conduct a sanitary survey around the Coosa River.

div1.head: Letter from Earl I. Brown to Henry Rose Carter, March 23, 1915
div1.opener:
FILE NO.
WAR DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES ENGINEER OFFICE
MONTGOMERY, ALA.
March 23, 1915.
EIB/FAS.
Mr. H. R. Carter,
Senior Surgeon,
U.S. Public Health Service,
Baltimore, Md.
Sir:
div1.p:
I beg to acknowledge your letter of March 12, 1915, stating that
you desired to make certain sanitary surveys at certain dam sites on the
Coosa River.

The Alabama Power Company I understand has acquired riparion
rights on the Coosa River at the location known as Lock No. 18, but have
not yet obtained authority from Congress to construct the dam at that point.
They made an attempt to secure Congressional authority for this construction
some three years ago, but the bill was vetoed by the President. It is not
known by this office whether they intend to make new efforts to secure this
authority or not. It would however be entirely agreeable to this office for
you to make a sanitary survey of the area which would be covered with water
in case a dam were constructed at Lock No. 18 at such time as may be most
convenient to you. Of course as the Company has not secured Congressional
authority to build the dam, work is not under contract, and it would require
some time even after securing such authority for a contract to be let. There
is therefore no certainty as to when the dam will be constructed at this
location. Should you desire to make this survey at the present time it would
probably be necessary for you to provide yourself with camping outfits and to
furnish your own subsistence. You would have to rely upon wagon tansporta-
tion as the river is not navigable at the point where this dam will be con-
structed.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully, Earl I. Brown
Major, Corps of Engineers. Ans-
